title: Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA)
icd10: M31.5 (Giant cell arteritis with polymyalgia rheumatica)
scope: ** Urgent diagnostic workup, empiric glucocorticoid treatment, and long-term management of giant cell arteritis. Covers cranial GCA (visual, neurologic), large-vessel GCA, overlap with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), vision-threatening presentations, steroid-sparing therapy, and disease monitoring. For isolated PMR without GCA features, GCA workup should still be considered. For other vasculitides (CNS vasculitis, PAN), use separate templates.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Elevated in >90% GCA; ESR >50 mm/hr supports diagnosis (ACR criteria); sensitivity ~80-90%
More sensitive than ESR alone; elevated in ~95% GCA; combined ESR+CRP sensitivity >99%
Normocytic anemia of chronic disease; thrombocytosis (reactive); baseline before steroids
Baseline before steroids; elevated alkaline phosphatase (hepatic involvement in ~30%)
Acute phase reactant; may be elevated
Cardiovascular risk assessment; steroid effects on lipids

Extended Workup.rationale: Elevated in GCA; potential biomarker for monitoring (especially on tocilizumab where ESR/CRP are suppressed)
Bone density before anticipated chronic steroid use

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h (before or within days of starting steroids; halo fades after ~2 weeks on steroids)
Essential/First-line.target: Halo sign (hypoechoic wall thickening); compression sign; stenosis/occlusion; sensitivity ~77%, specificity ~96%

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 1-2 weeks of starting steroids (biopsy remains positive for 2-6 weeks on steroids; do NOT delay steroids for biopsy)
Essential/First-line.target: Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells; intimal hyperplasia; fragmented internal elastic lamina; sensitivity ~85% (bilateral increases to ~90%)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: If stroke symptoms or cranial nerve palsy
Essential/First-line.target: Acute infarction (vertebrobasilar territory more common); cranial nerve enhancement; pachymeningeal thickening

Essential/First-line.item: Ophthalmologic examination (fundoscopy, visual acuity, visual fields, relative afferent pupillary defect)
Essential/First-line.target: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION): pale swollen disc; cherry-red spot (CRAO); visual field defects

Extended.item: CT angiography of aorta and branches (CTA) (CPT 71275)
Extended.timing: Within 1-2 weeks; assess for large-vessel GCA
Extended.target: Aortic wall thickening; stenosis of subclavian, axillary arteries; aortitis

Extended.item: MR angiography of aorta and branches (MRA)
Extended.timing: Within 1-2 weeks; alternative to CTA for large-vessel assessment
Extended.target: Vessel wall thickening and enhancement (mural inflammation); stenosis

Extended.timing: If large-vessel GCA suspected; assessment of disease extent; monitor treatment response
Extended.target: Increased FDG uptake in aorta and large-vessel walls (vascular inflammation)
Delayed choroidal filling; optic disc hypoperfusion

Rare/Specialized.item: Contrast-enhanced MRI of temporal arteries (vessel wall imaging)
Rare/Specialized.timing: If biopsy equivocal or declined; alternative to US in some centers
Rare/Specialized.target: Mural enhancement and thickening of temporal arteries

Rare/Specialized.timing: If aortic regurgitation or aortitis suspected
Rare/Specialized.target: Aortic root dilation; aortic regurgitation; wall thickening

Rare/Specialized.timing: If initial biopsy negative but clinical suspicion remains high
Rare/Specialized.target: Contralateral biopsy increases sensitivity to ~90% (skip lesions)

Acute/Emergent (Vision-Threatening GCA).indication: Visual symptoms: acute vision loss, amaurosis fugax, diplopia, AION, CRAO, cranial nerve palsy

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3 days (some protocols use 500 mg-1000 mg); infuse over 1-2 hours; then transition to oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day

Acute/Emergent (Vision-Threatening GCA).contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; psychosis from steroids
Acute/Emergent (Vision-Threatening GCA).monitoring: Glucose q6h (target <180); BP; mood; electrolytes; GI prophylaxis

Acute/Emergent (Vision-Threatening GCA).indication: Antiplatelet therapy to reduce ischemic complications (visual loss, stroke) in GCA
Acute/Emergent (Vision-Threatening GCA).contraindications: Active GI bleeding; aspirin allergy; concurrent anticoagulation (relative)

Acute/Emergent (Vision-Threatening GCA).indication: GI protection during high-dose steroids + aspirin

dosing.instructions: 40 mg PO/IV daily while on steroids

dosing.instructions: 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 60 mg); take in morning with food; maintain initial dose 2-4 weeks until symptoms resolve and ESR/CRP normalize

Standard Oral Glucocorticoid Treatment (.monitoring: Glucose; BP; weight; mood; bone density; cataracts; adrenal function

Steroid-Sparing Therapy.indication: FDA-approved steroid-sparing agent for GCA (GiACTA trial); reduces relapse rate and steroid exposure

dosing.instructions: 162 mg SC weekly (preferred) or every 2 weeks; self-injectable; can also use 8 mg/kg IV q4wk

Steroid-Sparing Therapy.contraindications: Active infection; hepatic impairment (ALT >5x ULN); diverticulitis; concurrent live vaccines; ANC <2000; platelets <100K
Steroid-Sparing Therapy.monitoring: CBC q4-8 weeks; LFTs q4-8 weeks; lipid panel q3 months; infection surveillance; GI perforation risk; neutropenia; NOTE: tocilizumab suppresses ESR/CRP -- cannot use these for disease monitoring (use IL-6 or clinical assessment instead)

Steroid-Sparing Therapy.indication: Steroid-sparing alternative (weaker evidence than tocilizumab); relapse prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5-10 mg PO weekly; titrate to 15-25 mg/week; take with folic acid 1 mg daily (except MTX day)

Steroid-Sparing Therapy.contraindications: Pregnancy; hepatic disease; CrCl <30; active infection; interstitial lung disease
Steroid-Sparing Therapy.monitoring: CBC q2-4 weeks initially, then q1-3 months; LFTs q1-3 months; CrCl; pulmonary symptoms (pneumonitis); folate supplementation

doseOptions.orderSentence: Folic acid (with methotrexate) 1 mg daily PO

dosing.instructions: 1 mg PO daily (skip day of MTX)
dosing.orderSentence: Folic acid (with methotrexate) 1 mg daily PO

Steroid-Sparing Therapy.indication: Alternative steroid-sparing if MTX intolerant (limited evidence)
Steroid-Sparing Therapy.monitoring: CBC; LFTs monthly x 6 months, then q1-3 months; BP; diarrhea

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Steroid-induced hyperglycemia not controlled with oral agents

dosing.instructions: Per endocrine protocol; anticipate afternoon/evening hyperglycemia pattern with morning steroid dosing

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: PJP prophylaxis if on ≥20 mg prednisone for >4 weeks with additional immunosuppression

Referrals & Consults.item: Ophthalmology/neuro-ophthalmology for URGENT visual assessment (fundoscopy, visual fields, fluorescein angiography) if any visual symptoms
Rheumatology for long-term GCA management, steroid-sparing therapy initiation, and disease monitoring
Vascular surgery for temporal artery biopsy (do NOT delay steroids while awaiting biopsy)
Endocrinology for steroid-induced diabetes management if persistent hyperglycemia
Neurology if stroke symptoms, cranial nerve palsy, or CNS vasculitis suspected
Cardiology/vascular surgery if aortitis with aneurysm or significant large-vessel stenosis identified
Physical therapy for PMR-associated weakness and deconditioning
Social work for steroid side effect management support and medication cost assistance (tocilizumab is expensive)
Nutrition/dietitian for weight management and diabetes prevention during chronic steroid use

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED IMMEDIATELY for any new or worsening vision changes (blurred vision, double vision, vision loss, shadows) -- this is a vision-threatening emergency requiring immediate treatment
Report new headache, jaw pain while chewing, scalp tenderness, or limb claudication as these may indicate disease relapse
Do NOT stop prednisone abruptly -- sudden discontinuation can cause adrenal crisis and disease flare
Take prednisone in the morning with food to minimize insomnia and GI upset
Monitor blood glucose as directed; report persistent readings >200 mg/dL
Report signs of infection (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria) promptly as steroids increase infection risk
Attend all follow-up appointments for blood work (ESR/CRP monitoring guides treatment)
Do NOT miss tocilizumab injections if prescribed; medication adherence prevents relapse
Weight-bearing exercise 30 minutes daily to maintain bone density and muscle strength on steroids
Annual ophthalmology exam for steroid-induced cataract and glaucoma screening

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Calcium 1000-1200 mg/day + Vitamin D 2000-4000 IU daily for bone protection during steroid use
Low-sodium, diabetic-friendly diet to mitigate steroid-induced weight gain, edema, and hyperglycemia
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular inflammation and cardiovascular risk
Annual influenza vaccine; pneumococcal and shingles (Shingrix) vaccination before immunosuppression
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy
Stress management and adequate sleep to support immune function and reduce steroid side effects
Fall prevention measures (steroid myopathy increases fall risk; bone fragility increases fracture risk)

differential.features: Younger patients possible; no systemic inflammation; "disc at risk" (small C/D ratio); no jaw claudication or scalp tenderness
differential.tests: Normal ESR/CRP; no temporal artery abnormality on US; no biopsy inflammation

differential.features: Recurrent pattern; no systemic inflammation; no visual loss (aura resolves)
differential.tests: Normal ESR/CRP; normal temporal artery exam

differential.features: Lancinating pain in V2/V3 distribution; triggered by touch/chewing; no inflammation
differential.tests: Normal ESR/CRP; MRI for vascular loop

differential.features: Jaw pain with chewing; tenderness over TMJ; click/pop; bilateral possible
Proximal myalgias; morning stiffness; elevated ESR/CRP; NO headache, visual symptoms, or jaw claudication
differential.tests: Consider GCA workup if inflammatory markers very high or headache develops; lower steroid dose (15-20 mg) sufficient

differential.features: Different vessel size involvement; different organ patterns; ANCA may be positive
differential.tests: ANCA; angiography; tissue biopsy; specific clinical features

differential.features: Cardiovascular risk factors; arterial territory symptoms; no systemic inflammation
differential.tests: Normal ESR/CRP; carotid Doppler/CTA; different vascular territory

differential.features: Elevated ESR from paraprotein; no temporal artery symptoms; bone pain; hyperviscosity
Fever; positive cultures; specific organ involvement
B-symptoms; lymphadenopathy; elevated ESR from inflammation
Multi-organ fibroinflammatory disease; aortitis; elevated IgG4; responds to rituximab
differential.tests: IgG4 level; tissue biopsy (IgG4+ plasma cells); different histology

differential.features: Large-vessel vasculitis in young women (<40); claudication; absent pulses
differential.tests: Age of onset; angiography pattern; no giant cells on temporal artery
Normal ESR/CRP; tender points; no objective inflammation

monitoring.frequency: Weekly x 4 weeks; then q2 weeks during taper; then monthly; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Rising ESR: evaluate for relapse; consider holding taper or increasing dose
Rising CRP: same as ESR; CRP normalizes faster and is more responsive to disease activity

monitoring.frequency: Daily (inpatient) if visual symptoms; each OPD visit initially; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Any deterioration: urgent ophthalmology; consider IV steroids; escalate therapy

monitoring.frequency: Q6h during IV steroids; daily during high-dose oral; fasting at OPD visits
monitoring.action: Insulin if needed; endocrine referral if HbA1c >7%

monitoring.frequency: q1-3 months (more frequent if on methotrexate/tocilizumab)
monitoring.action: Dose adjustment of steroid-sparing agent; infection evaluation if leukopenia

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months on tocilizumab; annually on steroids

monitoring.item: GCA symptom checklist (headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, PMR symptoms, visual symptoms)
monitoring.action: If symptoms recur: increase steroid dose to last effective dose; re-evaluate with ESR/CRP

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if large-vessel involvement; then q1-2 years
monitoring.action: Vascular surgery referral if aneurysm >5 cm or rapidly expanding
Ophthalmology management; IOP-lowering drops if elevated

disposition.criteria: No visual symptoms or stable/improving vision; oral steroids initiated; able to tolerate oral medication; outpatient biopsy arranged; follow-up with rheumatology/ophthalmology within 1 week; patient educated on visual warning signs

Acute vision loss or amaurosis fugax requiring IV methylprednisolone; new stroke symptoms; unable to tolerate oral steroids; significant steroid complications (severe hyperglycemia, psychosis); diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited workup
Acute stroke with neurologic emergency; aortic dissection from aortitis; severe steroid complications requiring ICU monitoring; rare: severe systemic vasculitis with multiorgan involvement
Neuro-ophthalmology or temporal artery biopsy not available; stroke requiring neurointerventional capability not available at current facility

All patients: rheumatology within 1-2 weeks; ophthalmology/neuro-ophthalmology within 1-2 weeks; PCP within 2-4 weeks (steroid monitoring); labs (ESR/CRP) at 1 week, then q2 weeks during initial taper
New visual symptoms (any); disease flare with headache/jaw claudication and rising ESR/CRP; severe steroid complications (psychosis, GI bleeding, severe hyperglycemia, infection)
